Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Thin Film Silicon Solar Cells on Plastic Substrates

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Photovoltaic energy conversion is an important industry for the future of the world?s energy system. The current production volume worldwide is over 2.5 GW/year, growing at over 40% per year. The current industry is based approximately 91% on the use of crystalline Si, and the growth of the industry has been hampered by the high and increasing cost of Si wafers.

Intellectual Merit:

This GOALI program focuses on developing low cost, high performance solar photovoltaic technology based on thin film Si deposited on polymer substrates, using a transformative device architecture.
This proposal addresses an alternative thin film silicon technology that can achieve a level of performance similar to that of thick crystalline silicon , while using only 1-2 micrometer thicknesses. The proposed work focuses on the investigation of novel device architectures including use of amorphous/crystalline superlattices, photonic bandgap structures and new material growth techniques to achieve higher performance in thin film silicon.

Broader Impact:

The program involves a strong collaboration with PowerFilm Solar, the leading U. S. company working on polymer based solar cells. The program will offer research and educational opportunities to both graduate and undergraduate students.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: 14.00 Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE The objective of this project was to develop efficient and stable nanocrystalline and amorphous Silicon based solar cells on photonic and plasmonic substrates. The substrates were both plastic (eg kapton) and thin stainless steel. The photonic and plasmonic structures were nano-imprinted into plastic or on steel substrates by our GOALI small-business partner, Lightwave Power of Cambridge, Massachusetts. Our other GOALI partner, PowerFilm, has shown a significant interest in adopting our new technology (superlattices) for thin film solar cells into production. Intellectual merit: 1. We successfully invented and developed a novel structure, photonic-plasmon, for efficient light trapping in thin film solar cells. In this structure, aperiodic arrangement of plasmonic dots leads to more efficient light coupling than is achieved by either photonic or plasmonic structures alone. The structures were fabricated and showed significant (50%) enhancement in the current produced by a nanocrystalline Si solar cell, a higher enhancement factor than achieved by any other technique for light trapping. Many papers were published in the scientific literature on this new structure and related device performance. 2. We developed a very thorough understanding of the role of impurities such as oxygen on fundamental electronic parameters such as defect densities and minority carrier lifetime in nanocrystalline Si. We showed that increasing oxygen concentration in the film increases midgap defects which in turn reduce the minority carrier lifetime. We also showed that the deleterious effects of oxygen can be overcome by compensating with ppm levels of B. This is important for commercial processing, because commercial reactors will always have oxygen as an impurity. 3. We invented and developed a new type of device structure, a superlattice solar cell incorporating alternating layers of nanocrystalline Si and amorphous (Si,Ge), which significantly increases optical absorption while preserving the efficient carrier transport of nanocrystalline Si lattice. This new device, when combined with the photonic plasmon structure of item #1 above, has the potential of producing almost as much photo-current current as a thick crystalline film of Silicon. This invention is likely to be very significant for increasing the efficiency of thin film Si based solar cells in the future. 4. We developed a new process for controllably shrinking the bandgap of amorphous Si by using controlled ion bombardment with argon in a layer-by-layer growth process. This discovery is important because control over bandgap is necessary for achieving the best performance in tandem or multiple junction solar cells, and we showed that one can change the bandgap of a-Silicon from ~1.8 eV to ~1.6 eV by using the layer-by-layer growth. Remarkably, the electronic properties of such films were excellent and the technique also improved the stability of the films and devices. Broader Impact: 1. Many graduate students did their thesis research or project research on areas related to this project, resulting in graduations of 7 Ph.D. and 4 M.S. students . 12 undergraduate students participated in our research, including three women students. 3. 15 talks on the subject were presented at international conferences held by IEEE and Materials Research Society. 4. In addition, many invited talks (~15) were presented to international audiences (universities, 4 year colleges, general audience), both technical and non-technical, during this period. In addition, we presented two IEEE webinars to worldwide audiences on physics of solar cells, and also taught two tutorials on PV, including thin film PV and nanocrystalline Si t...
